Introduction

Let us begin by exploring some of the musical instruments found in Caral, Peru, as shown in Figure 1:
Figure 1: Section of painel found in archaeological site of Caral, courtesy of ©ZonaArqueólogicaCaral (Ruta Caral, ; Youtube - Caral Perú Oficial, ). Photo taken on during a visit to the site.

?
Reflection 1: Couting with our body
There are more musical instruments in Figure 1 than we have fingers on our hands. How can we count these instruments?

Together we are capable

When we cannot count alone, we can ask for help. In this way, we are able to count:
First personSecond personThird personFourth person
Counting with the help of others solves our problem once again. But take a look at Figure 2, taken in Copán, Honduras, which contains the largest known text from the Maya region:
Figure 2: Altar, stele, and the largest hieroglyphic text at the Copan site (Instituto Hondureño de Antropologia e Historia, ). Photo taken on during a visit to the site.
This hieroglyphic text, present in the background of the image, requires multiple people to count everything. Let us think of another solution:

?
Reflection 2: Thinking together
Looking at your fingers, can you find another way to count?

Another solution

The necessity to count did not appear recently. It has existed for a long time, dating back to when there were no cities or houses built. We know this thanks to scientists who discovered bones with marks in different places (González Redondo, Francisco A., et al., , pp. 174 - 177, 180 - 182 ; Puente, Francisco Barriga, , pp. 21 - 23 ; González Redondo, Francisco A., ):

Figure 1: Representation of baboon bone adorned with markings. This image, credited to Enrique Silván Pobes, is featured in the scholarly work of Francisco A. Gonzáles Redondo et al.
The original is available in ResearchNet (González Redondo, Francisco A., et al., ), and its inclusion here is made possible by the authorization of Doctor Francisco A. Gonzales Redondo.

Over the centuries, various numeration systems have been utilized, some of which endure to this day. In the following sections, we present an overview of contemporary systems alongside those that have recently fallen out of use.
Observe that the marks on the bones resemble our fingers.

Conclusion

In this text, we learned that with the help of others, we can count even more, but we also observed that this does not solve all issues.
We also learned that after using our fingers to count, the next step was to make marks. This was not the only solution found. In the next texts, we will explore more options created for counting.
